body.p:
I avail myself of the first
trip of the Steamer hence to N. Y. to drop you
a line acknowledging your last, assuring
you of Mrs. Nathan's and my good health,
and cherishing the hope that this will meet you
and all our friends in the full enjoyment of
that blessing.

Nothing that can be in any way
interesting does it fall to my lot to inform you
of. Political revolutions bring about commercial
ones, and this little depot, for the manufactures
and productions of Europe and America, is much
affected by the stir which nations are making
to obtain from Kings and priests the liberty, rights,
and privileges of which they have, until now, been
cruelly depauded?. The events in the eastern hemisphere
and those in Venezuela are bringing our merchants to
the ground. Of course every one must suffer in
the general stagnations. The Synagogue is losing many
reliable members who are quitting this for America,
and I suffer among the number in the ?
of my income. In a year the Synagogue will be
too poor to support any one I have a mere Reader

were it not for the School my income as
minister would not keep me in board and lodging.
I am obliged to toil in that laborious profession
as before, when, I hoped that, after leaving Jamaica,
I should not be again obliged to resume it.

There is little or no improvement in
spiritual matters. Sometimes, I am half inclined
to blame myself as the cause of want of progress,
were the character of the people not so well known.
There is too much Hebrew here. It requires a being
of greater capability than I possess to effect any thorough
good. Thanks be to God we are quiet. I am grateful
for small things in despair of accomplishing ?
?. I have still? the rage for violent changes,
and even our friend Wolff is becoming orthodox.
The field of operation was better in Jamaica. I shall
never affect as much here as I did there. Still
Carillon's mad schemes are silenced for the ?,
and the accomplishing so much is an evidence
of the successful result of my ministry. People
are more strict in pot and kettle than formerly there
is good attendance at the Synagogues on Sabbath,
and holy days, and the children generally are learning
Hebrew, and religion. The girls generally are studying
the sacred language, and several of them show great
proficiency.

befallen us, and it is my duty, as a minister of
Israel to inform you of it. Incest has been com-
mitted, between brother and sister, and the fruit of
it was brought forth to the disgrace of us all. The
parties have left the Island, had they not, the General
would have sent them in chains to Copenhagen. The
young man who acted this abominably received
a German education. I doubt by this mean to cast
a slur on Germany, but on the parties who undertake
to teach without making religion the basis of instruction.
When Jewish parents send their children to a Jew
who has married a Christian, and yet who is a
Parnass of the Hamburg Temple, who breakfasts on
Kippur and then goes in solemn mockery to ask
atonement for his sins, what can be the result. The
unprincipled teacher will make a corrupt pu
pupil as in the present instance. Dr Fränkel
was the master, Mr. David Pretto son of Jacob Pretto
the pupil! The parents of the wretched children
are gone to the states the incestuous ? wish the
guilty daughter are with them. God grant they may
never attempt to marry the child (a boy) in the
Jewish family. I write this for your Guidance
should they come to Philadelphia. The child has
not been circumcised, as they went away before

the eighth day. It has afflicted every one of
us. We hang down our heads with shame.

I was lately in Jamaica, and was
warmly welcomed. Whilst there, somebody told
me that the N. O. congregation had written me an
invitation to come and be their minister, but if so,
the letter has never reached my hands. Carillon
applied to me to give him letters of introduction
and recommendation in order to obtain the
situation. I declined doing so, and gave him
as my reasons, his uniform bad conduct in ?
dissension and propagating improper and heterodox
doctrine. His eloquence did not move me. I
also refused to preach for him in Spanish Town, as
I would not aid him in the principle of sending
round the begging box for his benefit.

Pray give my best respects to Miss
Gratz and all her family; to my friends Mrs Hart
and Miss Louisa, Mr Abr. Hart & family, Mr Peixotto
your good land lady and Miss Couzens, if she be miss
Couzens still, and all my kind well wishers, send
me 100 of the Roads of faith. I hope you corrected
any errors without regard to my vanity or self-
love. Wishing you success in all your undertakings
in which Mrs Nathan and family ?.
